title: How many classes should I take per semester in college while working? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends upon how many hours you’re working and your other commitments. If you’re working full time, have a family, etc., it will be very difficult to be a full time student. You’re at work all day, and maybe have to stay late to finish projects. If you have a family, you need to spend time with them. There are only so many hours in the day, and something has to give, which means school gives. A good rule of thumb is to plan to spend 3 hours of class prep/study time per credit hour. If each course you take is 3 credits, that means you should spend 9 hours of class prep/study time OUTSIDE the time your class meets per week. If you take two courses, plan to spend 18 hours of class prep/study time per week. Do you have a spare 18 hours for homework, writing papers, doing research, etc.? If not, take one course. Yes, it will take you longer to finish, but so be it. If you’re working part time and are single, then you could go to school full time. A full time schedule is typically 4 or 5 courses taken per semester. Some colleges’ courses are 3 credits, so if you take 5 courses per semester, that’s 15 credits (unless you’re taking lab courses, which usually means you get an addition credit for the lab component, and this applies to both science lab courses and introductory foreign language courses). Other colleges’ courses are 4 credits, and their students take 4 courses per semester, which is 16 credits. The courses tend to be both broader and more in depth, so there’s more work, but it is okay. And it also depends upon what you’re taking. If you’re working and you’re in a demanding major, you might find that a full time schedule is too much, not if you want to and have to truly master the material. If you’re able to, you can scale back and you can always try to pick up electives during the summer so you don’t get too far behind.

It depends on your choice. When I started my education at the university, I took 2 additional courses over what the university allowed (5) per semester (I had to get special permission), as well as raise two children ( I was going through a divorce) and worked two part time jobs to meet ends. I maintained a 4.0 GPA for two years straight, then took a semester off which dropped my GPA to 3.8 for another 3 years (I was classified a professional student on the third year). Oh, why 5 years instead of 4 years? Social studies (history) teacher positions are notorious for ossified teachers who stay in setting for years. So its essential that new social studies teachers have alternative bases to apply for a teaching position.

Try to find a reasonable balance. How many credits do you need to take to keep your student status and any financial aid? How demanding is that job? Are you leaving enough time for yourself? What support do you have, say doing laundry and getting meals or do you need to add time for those things into your mix. Remember that you have to study, at least one hour out of class for every hour in. Then there’s time for writing essays, etc. Finally, there is human nature. I don’t think people should try to schedule themselves for more than 60 hours a week including all those have to do things.

A typical full course load at a college is 15 credits per semester or five courses. If you take a full-load, you should be able to work on-campus for 10 to 14 hours per week in a relatively flexible scheduled on-campus job. If you are trying to work Full time, off-campus and take courses, then you should take only two courses per semester and then take one to two courses in the college’s summer session. You need to check with the college to see what classes are offered over the summer. That will allow you to work full time and graduate within 8 years.

That’s based on how many hours you are working as well as the demands of the courses you are considering. Bottom line, if you are taking a 12-hour class load (often considered full-time), then you should keep your work hours to no more than 15–20. If you are working full-time, then I would recommend keeping your course load at no more than six hours.

Working full-time, I would limit myself to half-time status, typically 6 to 7 credits per semester. As a part-timer, I would stay as close to 12 hours as I could to keep my full-time student status. Some semesters, this could turn out to be 13 or 14 credits.
If you are exceeding 40 hours, more than 9 credits will be tough. If you are only part time, you can certainly go higher than that. At the masters level, I would not exceed two classes at once.
Figure you have at max 60 useful hours in a week. A three hour class probably needs 12–15 hours a week, including travel and misc. calculate time available from there.
